lines.text:
[First lines]
You've got to climb Mount Everest to reach the Valley of the Dolls. It's a brutal climb to reach that peak. You stand there. Waiting for the rush of exhilaration; but, it doesn't come. You're alone and the feeling of loneliness is overpowering.
[on the phone with her mother]

But, I just sent you 50 dollars last week, Mother. Okay, I'll send you 50 dollars as soon as I get my paycheck. You told me Gran's been sick, Mother, and I know about the oil burner. Okay, I'll take the mink to Uncle Ira's again. He'll give me a couple hundred for it. Mother, I know I don't have any talent, and I know all I have is a body, and I am doing my bust exercises. Goodbye, Mother. I'll wire you the money first thing in the morning. Goodbye.
[hangs up the phone and starts performing bust exercises]
Oh, to hell with them! Let 'em droop!
The only hit that comes out of a Helen Lawson show is Helen Lawson, and that's ME, baby, remember?
Who are ya hiding from, Helen? The notices couldn't have been that bad.
The show just needs a little fine tuning.
Don't worry, sweetheart. If the show folds I can always get a part as understudy for my grandmother.
Thanks. I already turned down the part you're playing.
Bull! Merrick isn't that crazy.
You oughta know, honey, you just came out of the nuthouse.
It was not a nuthouse!
Look. They drummed you right outta Hollywood! So ya come crawlin' back to Broadway. Well, Broadway doesn't go for booze and dope. Now you get outta my way, I got a guy waitin' for me.
That's a switch from the fags you're usually stuck with!
At least I never had to MARRY one!
YOU TAKE THAT BACK...
[pulls off Helen's wig while scuffling]
... oh my God, it's a wig! HER HAIR'S AS PHONY AS SHE IS!

[She's wearing a very large headdress]
I feel a little top heavy.

[Not meaning the thing on her head]
Oh, honey. You are a little top heavy.
Ted Casablanca says he's the joke of the town.
I wouldn't pay any attention to that. You know how bitchy fags can be!
He's not even 30 and he's made over a million bucks!
You've got your new deal, and I've got my sanity back.
With that little whore?
That little whore makes me feel nine feet tall!
Boobies, boobies, boobies. Nothin' but boobies! Who needs 'em? I did great without 'em.

[catching her husband in the pool with a girl]
Having fun, kiddies? Don't mind me. Go right ahead! I'll watch.
[girl runs away, naked, into the house]
You'd better run, you little tramp. How dare you contaminate my pool! Here.
[empties bottle of alcohol into the pool]
Maybe this will disinfect it.
Tony, how many times do I have to tell you? At night, all cats are gray.
I'm gonna heat up the lasagna.
I didn't have dough handed to me because of my good cheekbones, I had to work for it.
[after catching her bisexual husband with a girl]
All right, faggot! Start explaining!
You need glasses, Neely. She's hardly built like a boy.
I could take that better!
I'm sure you could. You know, you almost made me feel I was queer.
You're spending a lot more time than necessary with that fag.
Ted Casablanca is NOT a fag... and I'm the dame who can prove it.
Neely, you know it's bad to take liquor with those pills.
They work faster.
Do you realize, Miss Wells, that you are the most beautiful girl that ever left lipstick in my office?
You like women, don't you?
I like career girls. We're compatible.
There's a rumor they don't make very good wives.
Well, I'm not looking for a wife.
You're fortunate you know yourself. I don't know who I am, or what I want.
Take these papers to Helen Lawson, and don't give her any of that "I loved you when I was a child" crap, or she'll stab you in the back.

[drunk in a bar]
Who's stoned? I am merely traveling incognito.
Honey, listen, it's a rotten business.
I know. But I love it!
Well, what nice fattening thing did you tell Arlene to make tonight?
Arlene quit. She said you yelled at her.
She was a louse anyway. You said yourself she was taking home all the booze. Other people have loyal help. Why can't we?
You don't know how to talk to them.
That's your job. You'd better start running this house properly.
I'm not the butler.
You're not the breadwinner either!

I don't need pills like Neely. Sure, I knew you dried her out. But, it won't last. Neely hasn't got that hard core like me. She never learned to roll with the punches. And, believe me, in this business they come left, right and below the belt.
Mr. Bellamy, this is Miss Welles. She's here about the job.
She's too good looking.
I want a doll! I want a doll!
Jen! I can't feel my legs!
I wonder what happened to Neely O'Hara.
[snidely]
They SAY she had laryngitis.

[taking a drink - searching for a pill]
WHO HAD LARYNGITIS?
We're closing now, Miss O'Hara.
Shall I call you a cab?
I don't need it - I don't need ANYBODY. I got talent, Edward. BIG talent.
[Standing at doorway, thinking]
They Love me.
The sanitarium was very expensive!
Mel? God? Neely?... NEEEEEEELYYY O'HARAAAAAAAA!

[singing]
It's my yard So I will try hard To welcome friends I've yet to know! Oh, I'll plant my own tree. My! Own! Tree! And I!
[pause]
Will!
[pause]
Make!
[pause]
It!
[pause]
Grow!
Neely? Neely open the door, you're on. Neely!
Hi!
My God. You've got on your costume for the second act.
So? I'll do the second act first!
Let's go up to your apartment. We'll take the phone off the hook this time; so, Miriam can't bother us. How's that? Come on.
[Tony grabs her hand about to lift her up from the park bench]
Opp... My mother said I should have - held out - and made you marry me! Ha-ha.

[Looks at her with a frowning pout]
Ohhh... baby...

[Smiling]
When did I ever do anything my mother told me to?
[They hug and then kiss]
I'm Neely O'Hara, pal, that's ME singing on that jukebox!
Neely O'Hara sings like a bird. You sound like a frog.
Then I heard she went to Paris to make art films.
[laughs]
Art films? Nudies! That's all they are. Nudies.
You stupid ass nurse! What are you looking at?
Give me that damn wig! What the hell are you doing in there?
Giving it a shampoo. Goodbye, pussycat. Meeowwww!
[flushes toilet]
My God, she's throwing it in the can, I'll kill her!
How do you like that? It won't even go down the john!
Give me that wig!
Okay, you want it back? Here it comes, special delivery!
[tosses Helen's wet wig over the stall wall, then exits the stall]
So long, Granny. I'll tell your boyfriend not to wait.

Some days you'll have to work until midnight, having dinner with me and a prospective client. Now, I'll drink too much and won't remember a damn word the next morning. You'll have but one sherry and will remember everything.
I have an excellent memory and I love sherry.
How's your shorthand?
Weak; but, I type 60 words a minute.
Give me a fountain pen and not one of those lousy ballpoints.
You! Go back to the office and tell that son-of-a-bitch to get off his butt and earn his oats.
But, Miss Lawson, you haven't finished signing the contracts?
And I don't - intend to! Not until Bellamy ties a can to that little broad's tail.
Tell me, why are you dismissing us so soon?
Because I think show business is cruel.
Well, you're quite right. Oh, have a seat.
People do despicable things.
Yes, the certainly do.

Miss Welles, a raw recruit always dives for the nearest foxhole at the first burst of enemy fire. But, eh, don't let that happen to you. Don't you throw in the towel, just yet. This is a rather cruel business. But, it's also a great business and a rewarding business. For every Helen Lawson, there's always a Helen Hayes or a Mary Martin. Now, you think about that.
I can't stop thinking about that audience tonight. You don't know what it feels like, Mel, when they're all applauding and yelling and whistling. They did whistle, didn't they?
Oh, yeah, they sure did.
I felt like they were all taking me in their arms and holding me. It's like when you put your hands on me. Only it was - double, triple.
Mel, let's get married.
I-I thought you'd never ask.
I'm not kidding! I'll be making good money and with your 150 we can really live! We can get a maid to clean up! We can get a mink coat.
Are you wooing me, Mr. Burke?
If you wish to be wooed.
Offstage I hate her; but, onstage, I'm madly in love with her.
she must be beautiful; but, more important, she must be refined, cultured. A girl like Miss Welles, here.
That's not a girl. That's my secretary!
The girl will be identified with Gillian products, exclusively. I will start her off at 300 dollars a week.
Gillmore, that's sabotage!
It's also very tempting.
30 in the morning, still punchy from last night's sleeping pills. So, she takes a red pill to pep herself up and at midnight she's still flying. I try to talk to her. It's like a brick wall.
Well, I guess that's one of the drawbacks of being a big star.

The studio wants her to find out why she's so exhausted. They say they think it must be emotional conflicts. Conflicts, my foot! There aren't enough hours in the day. The head shrinker said she's - insecure. She needs mass love.
Maybe I'm lucky I don't have any talent.
Well, I've lost five pounds already. These pills are really great, Jen. They kill your appetite. Only trouble is they pep me up so much I can't sleep.
Now, you're just like all the rest of 'em. Success is too big for you.
If you ask me, my success is too big - for you!
Yeah, sure. Sugar!
Only in Hollywood do women faint because some queer danes to design their clothes.
I used to pretend - you going bald and fat.
I used to picture you with a sink full of dishes and a baby tugging at your skirt.
I am interested in a young lady with your, eh, your, eh, how you say?
Measurements.
Generally, a French girl is inclined to be - flat in the bosom.
I see. Just what kind of pictures do you make, Mr. Chardot?
Make? The art field.
Yes, I've seen a few. They're pretty raw. I mean, French subtitles over a bare bottom doesn't necessarily make it art.
You're always too tired and too full of those damn dolls.
You've got guts! I catch you red-handed with a naked broad in my pool and you sermonize me!
Not a sermon, Neely, just a few cold facts.
Ted, you know how hard I work. When I come home, I'm exhausted. How can I think of sex?
They're going to replace you with a younger girl.
Younger? Lyon, I'm 26!
You look 36.
What do you want me to do?
I want you to go to a sanitarium - and dry out.
A sanitarium?
I'm sorry, it's the only solution.

I'm scared. I've forgotten how to sleep without dolls. I can't get through a day without a doll. Please, Lyon, don't send me there. I need a doll! Lyon, don't leave me here! Just give me a doll! Just one! Lyon!
They ordered me to take off my nightgown. I told them to "drop dead". They took it off for me.
recreation hour. You never saw such a bunch of well breed kooks. They all acted as normal as apple pie.

I started playing checkers with this real cute looking little girl. All of the sudden, she leans over and gets a half-nelson on my hair and accuses me of telling the rest of the inmates that she's a latent homosexual.
Anne, honey, let's face it. All I know how to do is take off my clothes.
Jennifer, shame on you! Hey, still got that mole on your keister? Nope! They covered it up with make-up.

[Staring at her breasts and not the large headdress she is wearing]
Six hundred bucks for a headdress and not a soul will see it.
I feel a little top heavy.
Honey, you are a little top heavy.
I'll go out - the way I came in.
What am I going to do?
Anne and I want you to go to a sanitarium, in Los Angeles.
A nuthouse.
No. Its the same place that Tony is in.
Anne, I'm not nutty. I am just hooked on dolls!
I don't want to hear another word about quitting.
The going get's rough, they all talk about retirement.
Not me. I've had it rough before. I'm a barracuda.
Nothing can destroy her talent; but, she'll destroy herself.

And you, Lyon, you'd better watch it. Oh, sure, everything's rosy now. You skip from one thing to another - from one dame to another. But watch it, my friend. Find yourself a good girl. Have kids. Or, one day you'll wind up alone, like me, and wonder what the hell happened.
Boy, the old star sickness begins to appear. No more gratitude, just power!

Tomorrow they have to perform a mastectomy. The doctor says it's not the end of the world. He says lots of women live long and happy lives after successful breast surgery. The point is to catch it in time.
I'm sure they will, Jen. Afterwards you can come to the beach with us and recuperate.
"I have to get up at five o'clock in the morning and SPARKLE, Neely, SPARKLE!"
That old witch oughta to be boiled in oil.
A telegram for a Miss Polar. One second, you have to sign this. Thank you.
